name: (1Z)-3-(hydroxyamino)-1,3-diphenylpropan-1-one oxime
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-970

name: (1Z)-3-(hydroxyamino)-1,3-diphenylpropan-1-one oxime
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-970
Reason: To predict the melting point of (1Z)-3-(hydroxyamino)-1,3-diphenylpropan-1-one oxime, we will quantitatively consider the effects of different functional groups present in the compound relative to a standard molecule, here chosen as benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. Adding phenyl groups tends to increase the melting point by providing additional pi-pi interactions and enhancing the molecular symmetry, which typically adds about 20°C per phenyl group. The presence of the ketone (C=O) group generally raises the melting point due to the possibility of hydrogen bonding and dipole-dipole interactions, adding approximately 40°C. The hydroxylamine (NOH) group is both a hydrogen bond donor and acceptor, which would increase the melting point, estimated at an additional 30°C. However, the presence of oxime (C=N-OH) might introduce some strain and reduce the planarity of the molecule, which could slightly decrease that effect, by potentially -5°C. Summing these contributions yields the predicted melting point.

name: (1Z)-3-(hydroxyamino)-1,3-diphenylpropan-1-one oxime
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-970
Reason: To predict the melting point of (1Z)-3-(hydroxyamino)-1,3-diphenylpropan-1-one oxime, we consider how each functional group contributes relative to benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. Each phenyl group can add approximately 20°C due to pi-pi interactions and molecular symmetry. The ketone group adds more intermolecular forces via polar interactions, which can increase the melting point typically by about 40°C. The hydroxylamine group, contributing as both a hydrogen bond donor and acceptor, further raises the melting point; this increase is estimated at 30°C. The oxime group has the potential to form intramolecular hydrogen bonds which stabilizes the solid form and adds to the melting point; the estimated contribution is 25°C. Adding these functional group contributions together should give a reasonable estimate for the melting point of the compound.

name: (1Z)-3-(hydroxyamino)-1,3-diphenylpropan-1-one oxime
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-970
Reason: The compound in question features several functional groups that influence its melting point: the oxime group (-C=N-OH), the hydroxyamino group (-NH-OH), two phenyl rings (c1ccccc1), and a ketone group (C=O). The base structure of propanone (acetone) has a melting point of -95 degrees Celsius. Each phenyl ring, due to increased molecular weight and pi-pi interactions, adds substantial rigidity and planarity to the molecule, increasing the melting point significantly, estimated at +100 degrees Celsius per ring. The oxime group can form hydrogen bonds and creates steric hindrances, increasing the melting point; this effect might contribute approximately +40 degrees Celsius. The hydroxyamino group also contributes to hydrogen bonding, increasing the melting point, which might add around +30 degrees Celsius. The ketone group is already accounted for in the base structure of acetone.

name: (1Z)-3-(hydroxyamino)-1,3-diphenylpropan-1-one oxime
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-970
Reason: The target compound contains several functional groups, including two phenyl rings, an oxime group (-C=N-OH), a hydroxyamino group (-NH-OH), and a ketone group within its structure. Starting with propanone as the basic molecule, which has a low melting point, the multiple functional groups in the compound significantly increase its rigidity and its ability to form hydrogen bonds, both of which contribute to an increase in the melting point. Each phenyl ring adds aromaticity and further possibilities for intermolecular interactions, such as pi-pi stacking, which I estimate to increase the melting point by about +70 degrees Celsius per ring. The oxime group with its ability to hydrogen bond and dimerize can be estimated to increase the melting point by +50 degrees Celsius. The hydroxyamino group also introduces additional hydrogen bonding, which can be estimated to add another +50 degrees Celsius. Although the propanone (acetone) base has a melting point of -95 degrees Celsius, the presence of these functional groups substantially alters the melting point of the compound.
